Award.AwardTitle: III: ACM BCB 2015: Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Research in the biological and health sciences has been characterized by the introduction of novel technologies for investigations of molecular machineries, where a huge amount of data coming from experiments or medical practice has been stored in novel databases; new algorithms for studying functions, structures, interactions of proteins and genes, and classification of patients into disease subgroups that shares a common biological basis of diseases have been introduced; and almost all "omics" areas have been touched by new data sources with large repositories, new computational tools and applications powered by new algorithms. The ACM Special Interest Group on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics (SIGBio; http://www.sigbioinformatics.org/) was instituted in 2010 with the aim of focusing on research on bioinformatics data management topics, with a focus on bridging computational, statistical and mathematical sciences with biology and biomedicine. The ACM-Bioinformatics and Computational Biology meeting will provide a platform for researchers to bridge interdisciplinary research and also provide mechanisms to promote diverse and broad participation, especially through travel support for graduate students and young investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the annual conference of ACM SIGBio, the ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics and Computational Biology (ACM-BCB) conference aims to provide an interactive forum for researchers, practitioners, and students from around the world to promote scientific understanding and findings in bioscience, and to strengthen interdisciplinary research across computer science, mathematics, statistics, biology, bioinformatics, and biomedicine. The objective of this NSF grant is to seek travel support for a female keynote speaker and 25 selected students including 20-30% female and minority students to attend ACM-BCB 2015. This is to provide an opportunity for students to maximize their learning of advanced knowledge in bioinformatics and computational biology in the conference through the well-planned and organized activities, and will advance their research. If funded, this NSF grant will broaden the participation of graduate students and help develop the next generation of researchers and educators in computer science, biological science, biomedical science and other related areas.

 

 

The first key outcome is all the awardees earned this award by putting in technical work such as preparing a key research. The research forum enables these bright young professionals to exchange their research ideas, and to gain visibility from ACM bioinformatics and health informatics communities. 50 undergrad and graduate students, and post-docs young professionals submitted research abstracts. 26 did oral presentations with PPTs. One high school student presented a poster that was voted the best poster. One PhD student helped organize and co-chair the research forum.

 

The second key outcome as a requirement for receiving this award, these awardees attended the entire conference (oral and poster sessions) to interact with top bioinformatics and health informatics researchers attending ACMBCB2015. In addition, one of the awardees (Ms. Marzieh Ayati) organized student social activities (bowling event) for peer interaction and networking.

 

The third outcome on is on diversity. One of the keynote speakers (Prof. Bonnie Berger from MIT) and one of research forum co-chairs (Prof. May Dongmei Wang) are woman faculty. Among 26 presenting young professionals, there were 12 women, and two people self-identified (voluntarily) as under-representative minority. The women participation average is much higher than average percentage of women in computing, and this is a unique highlight of ACMBCB2015.
